CO2 capture and utilization has received worldwide attention in view of the goals of sustainable development and carbon neutrality. Ionic liquid-functionalized covalent-organic frameworks (IL-COFs) possess high adsorption performance and catalytic activity, which overcome the drawbacks of cycling difficulty for pure ILs as homogeneous catalysts and deficient catalytic active sites for COFs. In this work, BpCOF is first rapidly synthesized by solvothermal-scCO2-assisted activation method. Afterwards, poly(ionic liquid)s and metal sites are introduced into BpCOF to obtain Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF (R = COOH, CH3) materials through two-step modification including free radical polymerization and metallization. Then the CO2 adsorption performance, catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin and catalytic recyclability of the materials are investigated. The excellent diffusion behavior of supercritical CO2 and extremely low surface tension contribute to the rapid synthesis of highly crystalline BpCOF. The crystal structure and micromorphology of the materials are preserved after the two-step modification while the specific surface area and pore volume are decreased. The isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 for the typical sample Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF is higher than that of BpCOF, indicating the enhanced interaction with CO2 by the integrated poly(ionic liquid)s and metal sites. Then Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF serves as catalyst and the yield of cyclic chloropropylene carbonate reaches 99.3 % at 90 °C and 2.0 MPa for 16 h under solvent-free and co-catalyst-free conditions. The carboxyl hydrogen-bond donors (HBDs), Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites and Br− nucleophilic group in Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF play the roles synergistically. Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF exhibits excellent catalytic sustainability and reusability with the product yield exceeding 95 % after six cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Covalent organic framework Ionic liquids Free radical polymerization CO2 cycloaddition Supercritical CO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With rapid socio-economic development, sharp population growth and over-utilization of fossil fuels, CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is continuously rising, leading to an imbalance in the Earth energy and thus triggering global climate change. Taking effective measures to reduce CO2 concentration has become an important issue today. Carbon Capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) technology is a widely adopted strategy, in which the conversion and utilization of CO2 is an important part. CO2 is an economical and readily available C1 resource, which can be converted into a number of high value-added chemicals through chemical reactions [1–6]. Among them, the CO2-epoxide cycloaddition has attracted academic attention due to 100 % atom economy and no by-products. The cyclic carbonate has high added value and can be applied in different fields such as polar nonprotonic solvents, lithium-ion battery electrolytes, and pharmaceutical intermediates [7]. Therefore, studies targeting the catalytic conversion of CO2 cycloaddition are necessary. It has been shown that the energy barrier of the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 is as high as 209–251 kJ mol−1 and the reaction is not easy to be carried out without the involvement of a catalyst [8]. Therefore, the use of catalysts is essential. The covalent organic frameworks (COFs) has the advantages of high design ability, good thermal and chemical stability, which is beneficial for the regeneration of catalysts. Moreover, COFs materials also have an open framework network, which can provide specific nano-channels to facilitate the entry of CO2 into the active site and the diffusion of the generated products. However, due to the absence of nucleophilic sites in COFs, co-catalysts are often added to the reaction process in order to achieve efficient catalytic activity. Therefore, the combination of functionalized COFs with substances containing abundant nucleophilic sites is particularly significant. Ionic liquids (ILs) have high CO2 affinity, good thermal and chemical stability [9], and at the same time, the anions of ionic liquids can be used as nucleophilic active sites to promote the ring-opening of epoxides in CO2 cycloaddition reactions. The diversity of ionic liquids and their easy functionalization make the materials with great potential to develop catalytic systems for the targeted reaction [10]. Ander et al. [11] synthesized a series of phosphonium-based ionic liquids via a one-step synthetic method, and the best results have been obtained with dodecyltriphenylphosphonium bromide achieving almost full conversion (99.8 %) and excellent selectivity (84.0 %) after 5 h reaction at 160 °C and 40 bar of CO2. There are currently ionic liquid-based catalysts available for catalyzing CO2 cycloaddition. The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides catalyzed by this IL-based organocatalysts can be carried out at room temperature and atmospheric pressure [12]. However, the large viscosity of ionic liquids can hinder the mass transfer, while its homogeneous catalyst property is a problem to recover and separate. A variety of heterogeneous catalysts have been used to couple CO2 to epoxides, covering hypercrosslinked polymers (HCPs) [13], poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) composites [14] and ionic liquid-covalent organic frameworks (IL-COFs) composites [15–18] et al. Some of the catalysts have been applied as efficient solid organocatalysts for the capture and chemical fixation of diluted CO2 from flue gas [13]. For example, a family of multifunctional imidazolium-based ionic HCPs presented large CO2 uptake and high CO2/N2 selectivity and were extremely active in the coupling of diluted CO2 (simulated flue gas) with epoxides while it has high requirements for reaction temperature and mixed gas pressure [13]. A hybrid composite catalyst PIL@NENPs with multiple active sites was successfully prepared through covalent integration strategy and showed good catalytic activity under 110 °C and 1 MPa [14]. Based on this, the ionic liquid-covalent organic frameworks (IL-COFs) materials combine the advantages of abundant active sites, high porosity and stability of COFs, and at the same time overcoming the drawbacks of ionic liquids such as high viscosity, impeded mass transfer and difficult separation and regeneration. Also, the ionic liquids uniformly dispersed in the long-range ordered pores of COFs materials enhance the contact area with the guest molecules, effectively reduce the amount of ionic liquids [15] and improve the interfacial properties, which are more effective in practical applications. Among the IL-COFs composites, the impregnation method involves physically mixing ILs and COFs [16], while the active components of ionic liquids are easily lost and thus the stability is unsatisfactory; the IL-COFs obtained by chemical grafting were stable, but the limited number of post-modifiable sites in the COFs materials greatly restricted the ionic liquid loading [17]. In the free radical polymerization method, vinyl ionic liquid monomers are mixed with COFs materials, under certain temperature and initiator conditions, the ionic liquid monomers form poly(ionic liquid)s by free radical polymerization inside the pores of COFs materials. This method is also figuratively known as "ship in a bottle" method. Liu et al. [18] polymerized and encapsulated bis-vinyl ionic liquids with different carbon chain lengths in the pores of TbDp-COFs, the cross-linked poly-ionic liquids endowed the frameworks with a large number of anion-exchange sites, which facilitated the rapid transport of anions. In this work, 1,3,5-Tris(4-aminophenyl)benzene (TAPB) and 2,2′-Bipyridine-5,5′-dialdehyden-hexane (Bp) were used to synthesize BpCOF via solvothermal-scCO2-assisted activation method, which exhibited high crystallinity and abundant pore structure compared to that obtained by solvothermal-vacuum drying method. Then the vinyl imidazole ionic liquid monomers were introduced and further polymerized inside the BpCOF framework, Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites of ZnCl2 is liganded to bipyridine on the BPCOF. Finally, Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF (R = COOH, CH3) materials were facilely obtained (Scheme 1 ). The physicochemical properties of Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF were subjected through various characterizations. The design of COFs, PILs and Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites in the composite catalyst aims to utilize synergistic generated by the active sites and pore effect for CO2 conversion. A series of experiments was carried out to reveal the effect of different catalysts on the yield of cyclic carbonates. Notably, Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF exhibits the highest catalytic activity, achieving the cyclochloroallyl carbonate yield of 99.3 %, which is attributed to the favorable CO2 affinity and the cooperative effect of Zn2+ sites, −COOH and Br−. Under the same solvothermal reaction time (72 h), BpCOF-72h-vacuum obtained by vacuum drying shows no clear diffraction peaks and is amorphous, while BpCOF-72 h-sc activated by scCO2 has clear and sharp diffraction peaks, which appear at 2.35°, 4.03°, 4.66° and 6.23°, corresponding to (100), (110), (200) and (210) crystal planes, respectively (Fig. 1 a). Using the scCO2 activation, a clear (100) peak appears after 1 h of reaction. When the reaction time was extended to 4 h, BpCOF-4h-sc shows a diffraction peak intensity comparable to that of the sample reacted for 72 h, indicating that the scCO2 activation is capable of obtaining highly crystalline COFs materials and effectively shortening the solvothermal reaction time (Fig. 1b). The AA stacking model simulation of Bp-COF is assumed a space group of P3 with unit cell parameters of a = b = 44.8683 Å, c = 3.6645 Å, α = β = 90°, and γ= 120° The experimental results reveal that the BpCOF shows an ordered AA stacking pattern between layers. Figure S2 shows the rapid activation mechanism of BpCOF in supercritical CO2. The imine BpCOF exhibits a weak π-π mutual stacking interaction. Under vacuum drying, the capillary force during the decompression evaporation of organic solvents from the pores of COFs materials can cause structural distortion, resulting in poor crystallinity or even disappearance [19]. In contrast, scCO2, which is known as a "green solvent", has the characteristics of low surface tension and high diffusivity, which reduce the capillary force during the drying process, and thus the BpCOF material obtains a high degree of crystallinity and rich pore structure [20]. FTIR spectra indicates that the characteristic vibrations of NH (in TAPB at 3345 and 3420 cm−1, respectively) and CO (in Bp at 1694 cm−1) disappear obviously, indicating the full condensation between the aldehyde and amine. Strong stretching peaks of Bp-COF appear at approximately 1622 cm−1, revealing the successful formation of imine linkages. In addition, Bp-COF-72h-sc and Bp-COF-72h-vacuum show the same infrared spectra, which indicates that the post-treatment process does not change the basic chemical structure of Bp-COF (Fig. 1c). Figure S3 shows that different solvothermal reaction time has no effect on the chemical structure of BpCOF. For N2 adsorption-desorption experiments, the Bp-COF-72h-sc exhibit typical type IV isotherm curves at 77 K, which are indicative of mesoporous characteristics, and its BET specific surface area and pore volume are calculated to be 431 m2/g and 0.25 cm3/g. In addition, the hysteresis loop of the samples appears to be not closed, which may be related to the pore structure of the material. The larger material in small pores could not be completely removed by nitrogen at low pressure during desorption, making the curve not completely closed, this phenomenon was also reported in similar bipyridine COFs [16,21]. In contrast, the framework of BpCOF-72h-vacuum almost completely collapsed during the vacuum drying treatment, and the BET specific surface area and pore volume are only 4 m2/g and 0.002 cm3 /g (Fig. 1d and Table S1). Suggests that scCO2 activation is essential during BpCOF synthesis. The BET specific surface area and pore volume of the BpCOF material gradually increase with the prolongation of the solvothermal reaction time (Figure S4). The BET specific surface area and pore volume of BpCOF-4h-sc are 344 m2/g and 0.17 cm3/g (Table S1), respectively. On balance, the selection of BpCOF-4h-sc as the subsequent COF material. 3.2 Structure, morphology, and thermal stability of Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF A comparison of the XRD patterns of Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF composites in Fig. 2 a and Figure S5 reveal that the presence of the (100) facet at 2.35°, which indicates the BpCOF is still retained after radical polymerization and metallographic modification. Meanwhile, the material shows broad diffraction peaks at 22.8° and 24.3°, respectively. This is due to the presence of a large number of amorphous poly(ionic liquid)s flexible chains weakening the long-range ordered structure of BpCOF; in addition, the anions and cations in the poly(ionic liquid)s may interfere with the interlayer stacking of BpCOF, which in turn diminish its crystallinity. For FTIR, [VCIM]Br and [VEIM]Br exhibit the characteristic peaks of the imidazole group at 1664 cm−1 and 1163 cm−1. In addition, [VCIM]Br exhibits the peak of -OH stretching vibration at 3390 cm−1, and the CO stretching vibration peak at 1737 cm−1, revealing the existence of carboxyl group. Compared with virgin Bp-COF, Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF composites also shows additional peaks at 1664 cm−1 and 1163 cm−1, which are attributed to the imidazole ring [22], indicating the formation of imidazolyl PILs. The FTIR map of Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF is not significantly altered after the metallographic modification, which implies that the Zn2+ site is only partially coordinated to the bipyridine and does not change the framework structure of R-PIL-BpCOF [21]. The large introduction of the above two active components will be more beneficial to catalyze the subsequent CO2 cycloaddition reaction. 3.3 CO2 capture activity of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF The capture experiments of CO2 using the Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF were carried out to compare the performance difference with BpCOF at 1 bar, 298 K and 273 K, respectively (Fig. 5 a). At 273 K and 1 bar, the CO2 adsorption amounts of BpCOF and Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF are 0.99 mmol/g and 0.47 mmol/g, respectively. When the temperature increases to 298 K, the adsorption amounts decreased to 0.58 mmol/g (BpCOF) and 0.29 mmol/g (Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF). This is due to the increased thermal movement of gas molecules caused by the elevated temperature, which leads to an increase in the escape ability of the gas and causes a decrease in the adsorption capacity. The decrease in adsorption of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF can be attributed to the plugging of the pores by the introduced poly(ionic liquid)s and Zn2+ sites. The initial values of the Qst curves of BpCOF and Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF are 16.27 kJ mol−1 and 25.31 kJ mol−1, indicating that the adsorption of both with CO2 are physisorption process (Fig. 5b and Figure S9). The Qst of BpCOF does not change significantly with increasing CO2 adsorption, which is related to the surface homogeneity of the material [26,27,28] (Figure S9). The isocratic heat of adsorption of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF is higher than that of BpCOF, suggesting the introduced poly(ionic liquid)s and Zn2+ sites can enhance the interaction with adsorbed CO2 molecules. 3.4 Catalytic performance of Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF The synthetic functionalized Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF composites exhibit good CO2 affinity, possessed multiple functional groups such as Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites, hydrogen-bond donors (HBDs) and nucleophile Br−, thus their catalytic activities for the cycloaddition of CO2 and ECH are anticipated. For comparison, the catalytic performances of BpCOF and functionalized PILs were separately investigated and the results exhibit in Table 1 . BpCOF obtains only 3.1 % yield of cyclic chloropropylene carbonate due to the lack of functional groups (entry 1). In comparison, Zn-BpCOF obtains a yield of 28.8 %, which is attributed to the introduced metal Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites (entry 2). COOH-PIL obtains a yield of 87.9 %, which shows the excellent catalytic ability of the poly(ionic liquid)s, but the homogeneous catalyst is not conducive to the separation of the products and the recovery of the catalyst (entry 3). Based on this, the further synthesized non-homogeneous catalyst COOH-PIL-BpCOF gives 84 % yield of cyclic carbonate (entry 4). The Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF shows excellent performance with 90.9 % yield, higher than Zn-CH3-PIL-BpCOF (85 %). These results indicate that the synergistic effect between Br− nucleophilic and the metal Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites efficiently improve the epoxide-CO2 conversion, and the functionalized HBD groups (-COOH) further enhance the performance of the catalysts (entry 5, 6). Selecting Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF as the optimal catalyst for the CO2-ECH cycloaddition reaction, the effects of reaction conditions such as catalyst loading, temperature, time and CO2 pressure were investigated. Fig. 6 a shows the influence of catalyst loading, the yield obviously increases with temperature and obtains a yield of 93 % at 3.0 wt% catalyst dosage relative to epichlorohydrin. Meanwhile, the selectivities of the product cyclopropylene carbonate are all close to 100 % at different catalyst dosages. Therefore, a catalyst dosage of 3.0 wt% is selected for the subsequent reaction. The influence of temperature is shown in Fig. 6b, the yield is just over half (52.5 %) at 60 °C; when the reaction temperature is raised to 80 °C, the yield rises to 97.4 %; the substrate is almost completely converted with the reaction temperature further increased to 90 °C, considering the enhancement of synthesis efficiency, subsequent studies are carried out at 90 °C. The effect of reaction time is evaluated in Fig. 6c, after 12 h, the yield of cyclopropylene carbonate is 93.0 %; by continuing to extend the time to 16 h, the yield reaches 99.3 %, and further prolonging time, there is no significant increase in yield owing to the decline of reaction substrate concentration. Fig. 6d shows the influence of CO2 pressure, the yield of cyclopropylene carbonate is increased to 99.3 % at 2.0 MPa, however, further pressure increase has little effect on yield. Combined with ICP-MS measurements, the TOF of the reaction was 14.1 h−1. The reusability of catalyst is also important for practical applications. Thus, the cycle stability of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF was investigated. The catalyst can be regenerated by simply filtration followed by washing with ethyl acetate and activating by scCO2 (40 °C, 80 bar, 20 min) and then reused in the next cycle. Surprisingly, after the sixth cycle, the yield of cyclopropylene carbonate remains above 95 %, manifesting that Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF possesses excellent recyclability (Fig. 7 ). All the above characterizations indicate that Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF obtained by introducing poly(ionic liquid)s via the "ship-in-a-bottle" method and ligating metal sites via metallization has favorable catalytic recycling activity and structural stability. 3.5 Comparison of the catalytic performance of IL-COFs based catalysts Moreover, the comparisons of catalytic activity with some pioneering IL-COF based catalysts are listed in Table 2 , Compared with entry 5, Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF (entry 9) can be individually used for cycloaddition in the absence of solvents and cocatalysts. First, the substrates of ECH and CO2 are dispersed into the pores of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF, then the Zn2+ can be served as Lewis acid sites to activate ECH, meanwhile, the carboxyl of COOH-PIL as HBD also activated ECH through the hydrogen bond interaction (a) [37,38]. Second, the nucleophilic Br− contained in the material attack the β-carbon atom, leading to the ring opening to form the oxygen anion intermediate (b). [24,30,31,39] Subsequently, the enriched CO2 inserts into the intermediate and forms the carbonate ion intermediate (c). Finally, along with the intramolecular cyclization occurring, the cyclopropylene carbonate is produced and the catalyst Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF is regenerated (d). 4 Conclusion BpCOF was rapidly synthesized by solvothermal-scCO2-assisted activation method, which greatly reduced the synthesis time to 4 h, and sequently Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF composites were synthesized via two-step modification including free radical polymerization and metallization. The initial value of Q st for Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF (25.31 kJ/mol) is higher than that of unmodified BpCOF (16.27 kJ/mol), suggesting that the introduced COOH-PIL and Zn2+ sites enhance the interaction with CO2. Taking the cycloaddition of CO2 and epichlorohydrin as the model reaction, Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF as catalyst provides a yield of 99.3 % of cyclopropylene carbonate with a catalyst dosage of 3 wt%, 90 °C and 2.0 MPa for 16 h under solvent- and cocatalyst-free conditions. Furthermore, the Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF catalyst possessed excellent sustainability and reusability, with no significant decrease in yield after 6 reuse cycles (95 %). The remarkable performance of Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF can be attributed to the synergistic effect of nucleophilic Br−, metal Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites and the hydrogen bond donor carboxyl group. Meanwhile, benefitting from the low surface tension and fast diffusion ability in scCO2 environment, the BpCOF kept itself pore structure and microscopic morphology well after supercritical activation and avoid using more organic solvents. This study provides a convenient, efficient way to construct high-performance COF-based catalysts for CO2 conversion. coredata.dc:description: CO2 capture and utilization has received worldwide attention in view of the goals of sustainable development and carbon neutrality. Ionic liquid-functionalized covalent-organic frameworks (IL-COFs) possess high adsorption performance and catalytic activity, which overcome the drawbacks of cycling difficulty for pure ILs as homogeneous catalysts and deficient catalytic active sites for COFs. In this work, BpCOF is first rapidly synthesized by solvothermal-scCO2-assisted activation method. Afterwards, poly(ionic liquid)s and metal sites are introduced into BpCOF to obtain Zn-R-PIL-BpCOF (R = COOH, CH3) materials through two-step modification including free radical polymerization and metallization. Then the CO2 adsorption performance, catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin and catalytic recyclability of the materials are investigated. The excellent diffusion behavior of supercritical CO2 and extremely low surface tension contribute to the rapid synthesis of highly crystalline BpCOF. The crystal structure and micromorphology of the materials are preserved after the two-step modification while the specific surface area and pore volume are decreased. The isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 for the typical sample Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF is higher than that of BpCOF, indicating the enhanced interaction with CO2 by the integrated poly(ionic liquid)s and metal sites. Then Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF serves as catalyst and the yield of cyclic chloropropylene carbonate reaches 99.3 % at 90 °C and 2.0 MPa for 16 h under solvent-free and co-catalyst-free conditions. The carboxyl hydrogen-bond donors (HBDs), Zn2+ Lewis acidic sites and Br− nucleophilic group in Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF play the roles synergistically. Zn-COOH-PIL-BpCOF exhibits excellent catalytic sustainability and reusability with the product yield exceeding 95 % after six cycles.
